posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
But buggy as hell and uses way to much memory. Much room for
improvement.
posts.title: Beta 1. The system is feature complete.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
There is a lot to do to hash it out and make it more robust and
have better performance. But it is feature complete with a telnet
and web server that are both simple to use and extendable.

TO THE KING!
posts.title: Automatic fiesta is at it's first beta.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
This is the last big piece of the Automatic Fiesta system. With
this in place, writing software that can make your nodes respond
to web requests will be a sinch! A fair bit of it can be just
pulled from TelnetFiesta, so I'm already a good ways into this
process. But because telnet and ordinary http requests function
quite differently I will have to rework a fair bit of it. But
progress none the less! It shouldn't be to much longer now before
I have a full functional system. w00t w00t!
posts.title: Started work on AF's web server.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I can say pretty confidentally that telnet is up and running. this
is excellent news! Now the principles I have practiced with that
server I can make use of in making the web sever.
posts.title: Telnet is functional!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Got basic telnet up and running. mostly. Something seems a little
odd with it right now since it is complaining that there is a
syntax error on the first line after I added a bunch of comments.
I need to fiddle a little and see what is wrong, but for now I want
to save the work as it is so I don't loose it.
posts.title: Added Telnet.

posts.title: Initial commit

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
It's time for bed. But I got this basically to where I wanted it.
It is generalized so you can now setup a system relatively easily.
There is a bit of effort getting the interface setup properly, but
assuming you can do that, the rest is easy.

I expanded and updated the README.md preparing for a github
release in the near future.
posts.title: Just needs a touch of polish.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've started to break things up in a sensible way to make this a
library that can be reused more and hopefully distributed to the
world at large. It's got some ways to go yet, but right now I need
to do some sys admin stuff with my repos so I need this code
commited so I can move it.
posts.title: Progress towards a more sensible library.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I'm saving what I've got here now, but I think I'm going to take
this project in a bit of a different direction. I'm not going to
bother with turning this into a service, but rather I will try to
make it easy to use so that if a service is what you want, you can
make it your self. I'll just make this a library that is easy to
work with. And maybe a docker container.
posts.title: Maybe a change in direction is needed.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've not yet achieved making this a functional service. It's a
step that continues to alude me. I think I'm going to have to
devote a decent amount of time to the study of how linux services
are made and then I might be able to get this working the way I
want it to.

The good thing is that the functional side of it works just fine.
posts.title: Services are confusing.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've made a lot of progress. I'll still have to implement a status message of
some sort, but a great deal of progress has been made! woohoo!
posts.title: Nearly done!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've not moved the files to more sensilbe names. Also I have added all of the
cases for the python script to deal with the service requests. I'll just need
to implement them now.
posts.title: Moved files to new names. Added cases.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I removed the options so that you wouldn't have to specifiy anything at the
command line. I'll add a config file later, but for now this will help with
the creation of a simple service.
posts.title: Simplified the server a bit.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: I got the trigger class made. Just a start yet, It hasn't been hooked up to anything, but it is a start. I also figured out why my entire project would get rebuilt every time. It has to do with breaking things into .h and .cpp files. I've begun moving everything to be split like this and updating the make file. It is saving me a bit of time not having to recompile ever class every time.

posts.message: Alpha 11 complete. I now have all camera interactions moved over to scene, leaving Delta.cpp starting to look pretty barren. woohoo! Additionally, I've now got diffuse lighting enabled. so geometry is now actually visible as having distinct faces.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: I added a bunch of code for calculating normals for each vertex. I've started to work in the shaders too to get diffuse lighting working. I also have almost completely removed the camera form the main delta.cpp file. it is all handled in the scene class now, as well as programs.

posts.title: Alpha 10. woohoo! I've gotten every thing cleaned up and a new diagram. I added Program.cpp as it was getting to long. Camera is probably going to be getting there soon. I also wrote a make clean function so now it is easy to clear out the temporaries before commiting. I still want to get the temporaries out of github, I'll have to figure it out later.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Alpha 9! Fixed rotation, which was fundamentally wrong. got follow cams working, and made scene description work via XML. Doing so made it super easy to describe levels as well as load them. WEEEEEEEE! I did it. Alpha 9 is done. food time.
posts.title: Alpha 9! Fixed rotation, which was fundamentally wrong. got follow cams working, and made scene description work via XML. Doing so made it super easy to describe levels as well as load them. WEEEEEEEE! I did it. Alpha 9 is done. food time.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: I made a few tweeks to rotation. managed to track down a pair of minor bugs related to how objects were loaded and rotated. did some of the priliminary thought work for follow cams. I've got a good idea of what needs to be done now. Should have alpha 9 done by the end of the week for sure, alpha 10 is still a possibility.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Got quaternions working. rotation works properly now, better than it ever has and in probably its final form. now I just need to get cameras into the XML and follow cams working and this alpha is done!
posts.title: Got quaternions working. rotation works properly now, better than it ever has and in probably its final form. now I just need to get cameras into the XML and follow cams working and this alpha is done!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Got xml up and running entirely. that is fantastic. It currently only has the ability to load models, but cameras will be coming before the end of this alpha. can't believe I'm almost done with alpha 9! I'm soooo looking forward to doing alpha 10 for the retrospective and recreating the architecture chart. :) I am far to exited about documentation right now. ha! probably because I'm sleepy. hopefully follow cams tomorrow.

So the resource manager works on at least some level.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Cleaned up a little bit, removed a bunch of temp files and got all the dev docs uploaded.
posts.title: Cleaned up a little bit, removed a bunch of temp files and got all the dev docs uploaded.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Added a bunch a bunch of new classes, a lot of which aren't done/even started yet, but their files exist there. The main thing was the addition of the "buffer" class and the "object" class. I'm now staged to begin proper work on scenes. I also made it so that the program will automatically translate quads into triangles from .obj files. thus making it so that while modeling in blender, there need not be the concern to make everything into triangles.
posts.title: Added a bunch a bunch of new classes, a lot of which aren't done/even started yet, but their files exist there. The main thing was the addition of the "buffer" class and the "object" class. I'm now staged to begin proper work on scenes. I also made it so that the program will automatically translate quads into triangles from .obj files. thus making it so that while modeling in blender, there need not be the concern to make everything into triangles.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Initial commit
posts.title: Initial commit

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I'm drawing this project to a close for now. With this version I
have actually released the game to the play store. I really want to
recreate this with networking in mind. Make it a multi-player
multi-device game. But that will basically require me to rewrite
the entirity of the base logic to get it to work. To quote MM-M:

    Plan to throw one away.

This would be that. It's been good, but it's time has come. I've
learned a lot in this initial push, but it is time to move on to
a different project to continue my learnings.
posts.title: The one that is trown away.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I have accomplished two things tonight. First of is the icon. I now
have a place holder icon replacing the kivy icon for the apk. I'll
come up with something better later or have Kennan come up with
something. We'll see. But for now it is better than the default.
The other thing was explosions! Which actually has two facets.
First: A time delay when your ship gets destroyed. This allows you
a moment to realize that you've died. But further, this gives a
moment for debris to fly away! It's pretty forceful, espectially if
you crash into the sun.

Later I will make use of this time delay for allowing ties. It will
take a little effort since it will require a rework of the ending
code. But it shouldn't be to annoyingly challenging.
posts.title: EXPLOSIONS!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I added a makefile. For some reason buildozer won't compile the apk
on my NFS drive. I must copy the code to my physical drive and then
it will build properly. So the make file is just a save of that set
of copy functions. And then some where to remember the actual build
call to buildozer.
posts.title: oooh, two commits in one night!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I got so carried away with the debugging last time that I forgot
to commit. woops. oh well. So what have I done tonight?

Well, tonight specifically I haven't done too much. I got the
settings to work properly. This is good as it allows the game to be
playable again on handhelds. It wasn't work for a while as a result
of the config not finding necessary values.

Last time I coded I accomplished quite a number of things. I got
the settings screen up and running, if not fully working. I fixed
the issue where red wouldn't be able to fire until they recalled
their torpedoes at the begining of the game. Shots that collide or
fall into the sun now get removed from the counter. When you start
a new game, the previous shots are removed, clearing the gamefield.
And I added a score keeper. I'm intending to add a "first to x"
game mode in the rules, so this puts down one of the needed
components of that.

Left to do:
Add an icon.
First to x matches
ship selector
nicer ships
explosion on ship destroyed
sound

which honestly isn't a particularly long list! Hopefully I'll have
something up in the app store here soon. w00t w00t!
posts.title: I forgot to commit last time.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I did not get as much done as I had hoped I would. I have a managed
to get the game seperated out into screens now. That helps. You can
start a new game and it will throw up a victory screen and then
you can go back to the menu or play again. Progress to be sure.

What I'm slightly annoyed with is my lack of progress on the
settings front. I was trying to get the settings screen to work
and I just didn't quite get it because I couldn't figure out how
to get config to behave. And I need to go empty the litter box now
before going to bed. Hopefully I'll be able to accomplish more
later this week.
posts.title: Slow progress tonight.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I have added trails to the ships and torpedoes. It makes the game
much prettier and gives a better sense of movement seeing the trail
of the objects flying around. It makes the game feel like it is
actually a legit game and not some high school project.

Torpedoes now collide with each other, so you can theoretically
protect yourself from an incoming torpedo, though it would be
pretty spectacular if you did. I imagine it could work well for
spray and pray on an incoming torpedo.

The system for firing torpedoes is greatly simplified. But I did it
in a way that should allow for some fun later. I've got it set now
that you have one fire button and one recall button. This allows
you to just have a panic button that kills your own torpedoes
should you be about to kill yourself. The number of torpedoes will
also be something that can be edited.

I've made a burn down chart. 11 items on it before I can make an
initial release of the game onto the android play store. I hope to
do so in just a few more weeks like this one.
posts.title: Trails and Tuuuuuuuuuuuuuuubes!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've fix the launch speed of the torpedoes so they actually feel
shot now rather than just kinda rolled out of your ship. You can
start a new game immediately upon your current game ending,also it
provides a little note about who the winner is. Flipped the player
1 controller so it would be oriented correctly for tablet between
player game style.
posts.title: Much improved!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've setup the buildozer file and renaimed duel.py to main.py
becuase I'm comptent and totally know that buildozer needs your
code to be in main.py. But Tried it with wife, was funny. Needs
a fair bit of tweeking, but the bones are there and great.
posts.title: Buildozing!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I have achieved minimum viable product on this app. I'm going to
now try to load it up as an android app and see if my wife and I
can play it.

You can: Naviaget your ship, shoot torpedos, crash into the sun,
blow your opponent away, and blow your self away. You can also
shoot an unlimited number of torpedos and you can't self destruct
them. So this should be an interesting few games.
posts.title: Minimum viable product

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I am nearing on a minimum viable product. Things done today:

1. Joystick multi touch
I'll have to back port these to the original joystick repo. I have
fixed the problem where the joysticks would all respond to the same
touch as soon as that touch moved. Now the joysticks keep track of
what touch touched them and only respond to it.

2. Joystick mahts:
I've added into the joystick class the maths for all that you could
want from the joystick. Now, not only can you get the pad_x and
pad_y as percent of total range, you can also get the angle,
radians, and magnitude of the joystick. This allows you to work
with it in what ever form you desire.

3. Ship rotation.
4. Ship thursters.
5. sun collision.
6. started on torpedos.
Not finished yet, but I've started working on torpedoes. They are
currently having issues of being fired from not your ship. But I
have an idea on what could be causing that problem. The layout.

Lots done today! but now I need to research dancing for my friend's
wedding. Busy life right now. busy life.
posts.title: A dramatic step forward.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Name is probably taken, but it will be fine for a working title.
Game play is basic: Two ships in orbit around a sun. You try to
lob torpedos at each other around the sun. You have thrusters to
get into a better position, but you might just run yourself into
the sun. so be careful with thruster use!

I'm using the kivy Joystick I made the other day. I've already
found a problem with it. Two joysticks at the same time doesn't
work very well. I need them to track which touch they started from.
Mostly the issue is that on_touch_move doesn't check the touch it
recieved to see if it is the same touch as previous.
posts.title: Initial commit of Duel game.

kivy_joystick.description: An onscreen joystick for use in games.
kivy_joystick.name: Kivy Garden: Joystick

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
A commit futher down the road had removed the python 2.x style
super calls. I simply restored them now so it should be compatible
with python 2.x again.
posts.title: python 2.7 compatability restored.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: documentation: fixed some typos & added minor details

Cheers

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I believe I've got this already now for Kivy Garden. It was a bit
of a thing to try and get the pep8 checker working. I basically
just copied a number of files from the kivy designer over to my
dist-packages directory. I actually had to make the kivy/tools/
pep8checker directory in order to put the files there. It was a bit
of a mess.

But I can finally commit, as you can see. I did also make a few
changes worth noting. I fixed the issue where on touch move would
be picked up by the joystick even if it wasn't the joystick's
touch that moved.
posts.title: Preped for Kivy Gardening

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/Narcolapser/garden.joystick
posts.title: Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/Narcolapser/garden.joystick

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Initial commit
posts.title: Initial commit

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've got a little bit of polishing left to do on the code. Mostly
it will be removing commented code and removing debug print
statements, oh and adding comments for maintainability. But beyond
that it's basically done. Now I need to figure out how to share it
via the Kivy Garden.
posts.title: Finished it! Mostly at least.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I fixed the maths. The main the was that I was assigning it to
the pad's x and y verses pad's center. I also had to deal with a
flipped sign. Basically subtracting the widget's center from the
touch rather than the other way around (despite that being how I
left that).
posts.title: Fixed the maths!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
For a number of games I have planed, I need an onscreen joystick.
So far I have actually managed to get most of the behavior I'm
looking for programmed in. The last piece of behavior that is
needed is what happens when a touch starts inside the joystick area
and moves out. I tried implementing it tonight, but ran into some
bugs. It gets a little funky. Not sure where my math went wrong.

There will also need to be some work done to generalize it a little
more. Right now it basically has to be 200x200. I've put in some
calculations that attempt to deal with arbitrary sizes, but getting
a function joystick has been my first priority of course.
posts.title: Initial commit on Joystick widget.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I think I've got everything polished to a shine now. Going to push
this up to my website and go mow the lawn, boy is my brain tired.
posts.title: Some tweaks and updates.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I think I've got PDF export working again. It should now create the
resume pdf on demand so I can update the resume.json file and the
resume posted on my site should stay up to date. I also made a few
tweaks to the layout of the blog pages.
posts.title: Fixed pdf export.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I merged the react branch in and have updated the website's commit
posts now that the script doesn't get confused. Now I need to do a
little tweaking to my blog displaying and update my resume.
posts.title: Merged an more!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've updated the mark downs for various projects. A lot of spell
checking and grammar checking. Some needed updated content in
general. I rewrote the delta markdown from scratch as I haven't
touched it since 2014, and this website was certainly not even in
consideration back then.
posts.title: Markdowns marked up.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I made a few tweaks to the script that turns my commit messages
into devlog posts. I set it up to only harvest my commits so I am
not hosting other people's commits as if they were mine.

Also, it would seem the script does not want to run on my website
while it is in a different un-commited branch. So hopefully it will
work correctly as soon as I merge this into master.
posts.title: Updates to post generation.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Before I can really call this update done I need to update all the
data driven backend of it. So I've updated the markdown for
automatic-fiesta, dashlib, kivy_joystick, and o365. I've also
removed some of my older (and deader) projects.
posts.title: Added several items.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've merged these two pages as they were both rather sparce and a
little redundant. So I've merged them into one page. The other
reason is to get the about me front and center when some one comes
to the page to begin with. Make it a little more me focused I
suppose you could say. But hopefully in the "You're here to hear
about me, here's my info" way and not the braggart way.
posts.title: Merging of Home and About

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I think I've got all the functional aspects except for Resume up
and working again now. There are a few formating things that could
be tightened up but this is a good point to commit. I also need to
update all the data that backs the website. More recent gits more
recent readmes. Of course those are generated so it's not a lot of
effort but still it is something that I need to do.
posts.title: Projects is up and working.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've got the web log portion of the site up and running now. It
took an extra little tick because I render the markdown into HTML
on the server. I could do this in react but I didn't want to load
any modules in order to get my code to work. For now I'm using pure
react while I'm just learning my way around. I'm not sure though in
the end which I'd prefer, react parsing the mark down or python
parsing the mark down. But the important thing is that it works for
what I want right now.
posts.title: Blog is joggin.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've got the basics of the Developer's log working. It will display
projects and you can click on the projects to see the git commits,
such as this one, for that project. The great thing is that the
rest of the site is mostly a copy of this. Project and blog posts
are basically the same thing as the dev log so I just need to make
those components in their appropriate stylings.

React isn't to hard all in all. I do greatly appreciate having web
components in my site at last. It's been over a year since I first
learned about them and I've done vue and I've done polymer but
never got around to doing them in my own site. If it weren't for
the job offer at planning center I probably would have just done
vue. I'm glad I got to try react, I think it's cleaner, at least
with JSX. I wonder if there is a JSX Flask pluggin, that would be
pretty cool. Well, onward!
posts.title: It's all coming together now.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Missed a bit.
posts.title: Missed a bit.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've made a fair bit of progress for a single afternoon working in
react. I'll give it a little more effort tomorrow evening. Right
now I need to setup the ajax part of the site so that it can lazy
load the blog posts and such. But it is turning into a nice single
page application. Fancy!
posts.title: Trying to rebuild the site in react.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I cleaned up the code base a fair bit as I am starting to make it
PEP8 compliant. I'm also starting to use full words more often.
This is partly do to me trying to use PyCharm as my ide. It's come
again, the "I should really use an IDE" inklings. I think I may
actually follow through on it this time. PyCharm isn't hindering me
to terribly so I should be able to get over the hump to the point
where it starts to accelerate me. Here's hoping.
posts.title: Cleaning up and pressing on.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Merge branch 'master' of gitlab.com:narcolapser/studiosleepygiraffe
posts.title: Merge branch 'master' of gitlab.com:narcolapser/studiosleepygiraffe

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've decided to switch to python3. This actually only has effects
on one point of the code base, StringIO has been replaced with just
io. Considering that is for the "snow" blueprint I may not even
keep that around so the end result is a python agnostic code base.

I've also added basic tracking. Now every request gets recorded
into a database that I can query later. I don't know if anyone sees
my site but this should give me some idea and using geo-ip I can
potentially get some geographical data out of it. Since the purpose
of this website is to be a portfolio it would be nice to see who
is looking at it from where. The who will be quite challenging, but
the IP is enough for the where. Once I have that information then
I'd like to make some sort of display.
posts.title: Python3 and Tracking.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Conflicts:
	studiosleepygiraffe/__init__.py
posts.title: Merge branch 'resume'

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
There was a problem that was outstanding for a while that I've been
wanting to fix but have never gotten around to it. blog posts have
tags that when you click on them link you to a tags page so you can
see all other posts with those tags. That last piece of it wasn't
working. It would take you to a blank page. Got that sorted. I also
moved the blog subsystem to its own blue print. This drops my
__init__.py file down to about 100 lines of code. Probably about
half the size it was when I started this endevour. Jolly good.
posts.title: Updates to blog linking.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I have started working migrating my code to blueprints so that I
can work on it a lot easier. So I have moved the whole snow removal
reporting subsystem out of __init__.py. I'll now move on to other
parts of the website out to keep things nice and simpel.

I also added a .gitignore, don't know how I missed that.
posts.title: Start of the blueprinting process.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I wanted to be able to control my kitchen lights from IFTTT, so
I wrote a script that will allow me to pass through the commands
with out actually opening my home network to arbitrary html
requests. That would be bad.

This isn't entirely great since theoretically anyone could find
this and take control of our kitchen lights. I'm not to concerned
because that's a worthless target. They only draw 1A 12V so it's
not like it can be used like our AC for malicious power grid
attacks or anything like that. The worst they could do is make
them constantly flash.
posts.title: Added some basic home automation.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've added a resume feature to my website. Like everything it is
data driven. I have a template for the skeleton of the resume but
a JSON file is loaded that populates it with data. This commit is
just a basic setup. I've copied in all of my information from my
previous resume into the json file and formated it in a similar
way. Honestly it looks somewhere between crap and bland. But it's a
first step. Now that I've got the skeleton and data there I will
clean up the template to make it look nicer and update the info
in resume.json to be more accurate of recent developments.
posts.title: Resume is now available, but needs some love.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I decided to merge this in. I'm going to bring both snow and house pics
to the master branch so I stop having an awkward half baked master
branch. When the time comes I'll just remove these features. This is
one of the glory's of git really.
posts.title: Merge branch 'snow' into housepics

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I added a system for creating snow shoveling invoices for my mom.
She has me shovel snow outside the sorority she manages on occation
and I wanted a nice simple way to keep track and make invoices for
billing purposes. These are the invoices that get sent to the board
so they need to look some what professional. I've also set it up to
be easy to add each clearing and then re-generate the pdf. Now all
I have to do is edit snow.csv, adding the days I shoveled snow and
then at the end of the month, vist the PDF and down load it.
Because of the rarity in which I need this feature, I'll probably
not push it to carbon.
posts.title: Snow removal!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Merge branch 'master' into housepics
posts.title: Merge branch 'master' into housepics

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Just a few little tweaks to get the json blog stuff working fully
and correctly. I landed on using a hybrid system of json files and
mark down files. Becuase writing a markdown file inside a json file
is a terrible idea.  So instead, it gets both. You can specify in
the json file what the markdown file is for the blog post.
posts.title: Json blog refinement.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've been working a little bit on fleshing out the blog side of
things. I now specifies that it was writen by me and what date,
I'm not sure I need the author bit, but it's nice. I also added the
ability to include a cover photo. These were achieved through
making the content json instead of plain text files. The content of
the post however remains mark down so I can still do formating.

I also was working on tags for the posts. Ideally you'll be able to
click on a tag in the post and see other posts that also have that
tag. Just making the site feel complete really. I've thought about
adding a similar feature to my git posts. Which I really need to
dig into a little deeper anyway.
posts.title: More blog features!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I added two new utility scripts to keep everything up to date and
safe. The first is a script that goes through all of the repos
locally on carbon and pulls down the latest versions from mycroft.
After doing this then the website's info can be updated, but that
will be part of a pipeline sort of thing I develop later. The
important thing is that I don't have to do each independantly now.

The second script makes an archive. It tarballs all the repos
together and sends a copy over to mycroft. In it's final form it
will also delete the tarball from carbon, but I had a hard drive
scare a bit ago and so I don't want to leave all my data on
mycroft. I plan on running this about once a week. Version control
is plenty good, but I just want a backup my backup as the saying
goes. Eventually this will upload to the cloud somewhere.
posts.title: Backup and refresh

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Put the index to home.html
posts.title: Put the index to home.html

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Merge branch 'master' into housepics
posts.title: Merge branch 'master' into housepics

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Common problem. Forgot to add the new files related to the blog
portion of the site and the NCS player pictures.
posts.title: Forgot the new files.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I decided to add a blog. More details on why in my blog. Basically
git posts and the project pages weren't quite sufficent for what I
needed. I had content I wanted to post but no where to put it since
all content had to be directly related to one of my projects.

Also new in this commit is the NCS Player. NCS Player is a proof of
concept project. I have plans to make a video streaming app for
independant content creators, but first I wanted to experiment
around with something a little more constrained in scope.
posts.title: NCS Player and blog.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Merge branch 'housepics' of mycroft:/media/toben/Eurus/ssg_projects/studiosleepygiraffe into housepics
posts.title: Merge branch 'housepics' of mycroft:/media/toben/Eurus/ssg_projects/studiosleepygiraffe into housepics

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Conflicts:
	studiosleepygiraffe/__init__.py
posts.title: Merge branch 'active' into housepics

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Merge branch 'master' into housepics
posts.title: Merge branch 'master' into housepics

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Not much changed in this commit. I've added pictures for o365,
automatic fiest, and dashlib. I also rearranged the repos a little.
I moved Dashlib up, reflecting it's maturity over some of the other
projects.

But the excitment tonight is I've got a published game! Gravity
Duel is now available on the google play store! I've acctually
accomplished it! I have a published game! w00t! So I wanted to
throw a little polish onto my website in celebration. I'm so happy!
posts.title: Night of publishing.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've centered the titles on all the pages, I also got the navbar to
be centered. Makes it look a lot more intentional now.
posts.title: The centering of things!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Up to 10 now that I'm including on my website. They range from the
"Wait, I decided that was worth talking about?" To O365, a like
legitamate library that has a fairly substantial following. Though
I will now need to get some more pictures for the other projects.

I'm moving all of my repos from various locations to being hosted
on mycroft primarily. From there the repos will be cloned to my
disprate machines, or disprate locations on the same machine. This
centeralizing simplifies things by making my life a little more
consistent and organized. I'm also having each project cloned
locally on carbon so that the utility scripts can find the projects
easily.
posts.title: More projects!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I think I've got it to a basic presentable level. I set all but
the projects tab to fill only 50% of the screen so it's not spread
so thin. Projects will probably need some formating of their own,
but for now this will do. I also changed the name from "apps" to
"projects" since that more accurately reflects the nature of them.
It isn't so much individual programs as much as it is various
projects that I am working on.
posts.title: Presentable.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Extra little bits.
posts.title: Extra little bits.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've added a few things and changed the default home page to allow
for family to see the pictures of houses we are looking at. This
will probably go away in the near future, but it is convenient for
now.

It took a little effort, but I even got lazy loading working on
this. So the images now load when you call for them, and no
earlier. That should keep it's load time low and also keep it very
responsive.
posts.title: Temporary house viewer.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've not got pictures for all of my current projects. Several of
them aren't great, but they are sufficent. Place holders at very
least.

I made a few tweaks to the style.css trying to get it to put my
picture inline with the text, no luck. Curse you HTML/CSS! Not
behaving exactly as I want. How rude!

There was a small issue with the dev logs, the white space was not
being rendered at all. This meant all my messages were just getting
crunched together. There was an idea for a way to fix this that was
rendering your content ask markdown and running it through a
parser. This idea has merit. I could put markdown formating in my
git commit messages to get even more information crammed into them.
posts.title: Finished the pictures.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've made a huge pile of changes with this commit. Pictures have
been added to most of the apps on the apps page. the pictures will
naturallly flow behind the text for each application. I put down
some basic pieces for about and contact, though some tweeking is
still necessary. I've added a discription for each app.

Over all this is really starting to close in on being a fleshed out
website the way have been envisioning/desiring. I'm pleased! Just
a little more and I'll be able to make it public facing.
posts.title: Things are looking good!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I changed all the templates to use inheritance from a base
template, ssg.html. This makes each template just a little bit
simplier and avoids me repeating myself. DRY woohoo!

I also expanded the README.md quite a bit. I explained how the
whole git-posting system works and why I use markdown for the
project pages.

My next work will be in making things a little more fancy. I've
got several ideas written down in my sketch book on how to make the
apps page more exciting. I intend on making each app a kind of
button with text and images inside. But of course automatically
generated so I don't have to bog myself down with creating content
for the website. Let the website create itself!
posts.title: Template inheritance now in use.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've got style actually starting to appear on the website now. I
banged my head against the flask-bootstrap templates for a while
but in the end decided to not use the base templates and instead
create my own. This requires a little more effort, but it allows me
a lot more control. Since HTML is still something I'm trying to
master, keeping it simple is a great help.

I've downloaded a bootstrap css style. I can easily change the
style of my whole site but just swapping these files out. Pretty
neat really! Right now I've just choosen a simple black style. I'm
found of sites that are primarily dark colors, it feels less
straining to look at. As I add pictures and things, it may be less
of a deal and I'll probably switch to a lighter style, but this
works for now.
posts.title: Style is coming!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: I've added the read me for the website's repo. Just space duel left to have a read me. Then each project will have it's own description page.
posts.title: Added README.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Conflicts:
	studiosleepygiraffe/__init__.py
posts.title: Merge branch 'git-post'

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've decided to leverage the README.md file for the summary of the
app. I'll probably end up doing something more interesting in the
future, but this is certainly a functional first step, something
that allows me to get this website up sooner than later.

I've also re-arranged things a bit. I've moved my git-post/posts.py
file into utility-scripts/ folder. It and copy-markdown.py are the
occupants of my new utility-scripts folder. These are scripts I'll
have to run periodically for now to get the data to show.
posts.title: Apps now does it's own thing.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Merge branch 'git-post'
posts.title: Merge branch 'git-post'

posts.author: Toben Archer

posts.title: Merge branch 'git-post' of ssh://studiosleepygiraffe.com:41990/home/toben/Eurus/ssg projects/studiosleepygiraffe into git-post

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
Things can get a bit hap hazard when you are developing across 3
git repos at once!
posts.title: Missed a file.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Missed a forward slash.
posts.title: Missed a forward slash.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
A small fix, but I have updated the pathing for resources. While
resource/projects.json worked fine for the dev enviorment, it was
failing in production. So I added a bit that I found on stack
overflow: https://stackoverflow.com/q/14825787

This introduced me to getting the location of the current file and
saving it as APP_ROOT. This should work in both dev and prod.
posts.title: APP_ROOT

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I also updated the devlog templates. I'm moving the autoblogging
over to the devlog tab like it supposed to be. I'll do write ups
for the apps section probably next. Those to will probably also be
automated deally bobs. I think I'll use the README.md files for
that. This way I can maintain a nice summary page while in the
code as usual. I'll probably have this whole site automated by the
time I actually feel like publishing it. xD
posts.title: Merge branch 'nickle' into git-post

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message: Artifacts.
posts.title: Artifacts.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I had to make a few tweaks to the output to make it easier to work
with. Should be good to use now.
posts.title: Some tweeks.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I got the posts.py file working like I want it to now. Turns out
there was a trailing '\n' causing all the problems. But I decided
to upgrade the repos file to use json so I could add more info to
the projects.

In looking at this, I might release this as it's own project in the
future. Autoblogging via git commit messages is pretty knifty and
I think more people than just me would enjoy it. We'll see. Right
now I'm jsut happy to get all the projects in to the system.
posts.title: Works now!

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
It is mostly done as a matter of crossed wires. But I've added the
feature where commits are posted as blog entries to the apps page.
Not entirely intentional. But I was already down that rabbit hole
so I kept going. I'll make the appropriate changes soon to move the
git commit auto blogging over to the dev log page, which I've yet
to make. ^^;

But it's progress! The site is starting to have some idea of the
content that I want in it available. And I'm slowly starting to
understand how to piece it all together. It is my first flask app
after all. Man, never thought I'd be making web apps. I suppose I
never really fancied myself as a mobile developer either. But here
we are. Making kivy and flask apps.

TO THE KING!
posts.title: Apps now are devlogs! Wait.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
I've added a little more to this. Now there are "posts" that will
encapsulate all the information for a post. I've run into a problem
however which I'm not sure what is causing it. That sentence got
weird. I think the user not being able to access the git repo is
basically the problem. Which is probably do to clever tricks with
the NFS mount not being quite as clever as I want.
posts.title: Created post objects.

posts.author: Toben Archer
posts.message:
This too will one day become a blog post. I'll probably have single
line commits be ignored, or tweeted or something. But right now
just got it set up so that it will find git commit messages and
turn them into a title and a body.
posts.title: Started work on system for having posts done by git commits.
